verses.text: The LORD appeared to Abraham by the oaks of Mamre, as he sat at the entrance of his tent in the heat of the day.
verses.comment: God's appearance here is one of several theophanies to Abraham. The location is significant for later covenants.

verses.text: He lifted up his eyes and looked, and behold, three men stood before him. When he saw them, he ran from the entrance of his tent to meet them and bowed himself to the ground.
verses.comment: The three men can be understood symbolically, hinting at the mystery of the Trinity, though literally angels and the LORD are present.

verses.text: He said, 'My Lord, if now I have found favor in your eyes, do not pass by your servant.'
verses.comment: The phrase 'My Lord' is both a term of respect and, in context, can be understood as addressing God.

verses.text: 'Let a little water be brought, and wash your feet, and rest yourselves under the tree.'
verses.comment: Hospitality in the ancient world reflected humility and service, foreshadowing Christ washing the disciples' feet.

verses.text: 'And I will bring a morsel of bread, that you may refresh your hearts. After that you may pass on, since you have come to your servant.' So they said, 'Do as you have said.'
verses.comment: Sharing bread continues through the Scriptures as a sign of fellowship and blessing.

verses.text: Abraham hurried into the tent to Sarah and said, 'Quick! Three measures of fine flour, knead it, and make cakes.'
verses.comment: The quantity—three measures—foreshadows later references to bread and teaching in the New Testament.

verses.text: And Abraham ran to the herd, took a tender and good calf, and gave it to a servant, who hurried to prepare it.
verses.comment: The offering of the calf shows Abraham's generosity, prefiguring sacrificial elements later fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: He took curds, milk, and the calf he had prepared, and set it before them; and he stood by them under the tree while they ate.
verses.comment: Eating together signifies deep fellowship; God's communion with His people is echoed here and later in the Eucharistic themes of the NT.

verses.text: They said to him, 'Where is Sarah your wife?' He said, 'She is in the tent.'
verses.comment: God's interest in Sarah highlights the personal nature of His covenant promises.

verses.text: And he said, 'I will surely return to you about this time next year, and Sarah your wife shall have a son.' Now Sarah was listening at the entrance of the tent, which was behind him.
verses.comment: The prophecy of Isaac’s birth, echoing many Biblical themes of miraculous births (see also Luke 1:13, 1:34–35).

verses.text: Now Abraham and Sarah were old, advanced in age. Sarah had stopped having the way of women.
verses.comment: Sarah’s barrenness magnifies the miracle and the faith required to believe God’s promise.

verses.text: So Sarah laughed to herself, saying, 'After I am worn out, and my lord is old, shall I have pleasure?'
verses.comment: Her laughter is both incredulous and prophetic, as Isaac’s name means ‘he laughs’.

verses.text: The LORD said to Abraham, 'Why did Sarah laugh and say, "Shall I indeed bear a child, now that I am old?"'
verses.comment: God’s knowledge of Sarah’s thoughts shows His omniscience, an attribute seen throughout Scripture (see 1 Sam. 16:7).

verses.text: 'Is anything too hard for the LORD? At the set time I will return to you, and Sarah shall have a son.'
verses.comment: A key verse on the omnipotence of God, and cited in the NT concerning God's power to fulfill promises.

verses.text: But Sarah denied it, saying, 'I did not laugh,' because she was afraid. He said, 'No, but you did laugh.'
verses.comment: Even in human weakness, God follows through with His plan. Fear often precedes faith when encountering the divine.

verses.text: Then the men rose up from there and looked toward Sodom. And Abraham went with them to set them on their way.
verses.comment: The connection between Abraham’s hospitality and the impending judgment on Sodom suggests the value of virtue and intercession.

verses.text: The LORD said, 'Shall I hide from Abraham what I am about to do?'
verses.comment: This communicates the privileged relationship that Abraham enjoys. Similar language is used by Jesus with His disciples.

verses.text: 'Since Abraham will surely become a great and mighty nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed in him.'
verses.comment: The promise of blessing to all nations is foundational, later fulfilled in Christ through faith.

verses.text: 'For I have known him, so that he may command his children and his household after him to keep the way of the LORD by doing righteousness and justice, that the LORD may bring upon Abraham what He has spoken of him.'
verses.comment: 'Knowing' Abraham signals a covenantal relationship; the transmission of faith through family is highlighted.

verses.text: The LORD said, 'Because the outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is great, and their sin is very grievous.'
verses.comment: The seriousness of sin and its consequences is stressed; collective morality influences divine judgment.

verses.text: 'I will go down now and see whether they have done altogether according to the outcry that has come to Me. And if not, I will know.'
verses.comment: God’s investigation echoes His justice; it is pedagogical for us, as God knows all, but shows He acts justly.

verses.text: The men turned from there and went toward Sodom, but Abraham stood still before the LORD.
verses.comment: Abraham’s intercessory stance before God is archetype for mediation and prayer on behalf of others.

verses.text: Abraham drew near and said, 'Will you indeed sweep away the righteous with the wicked?'
verses.comment: Abraham appeals to God’s justice, initiating persistent prayer and negotiation.

verses.text: 'Suppose there are fifty righteous within the city. Will you sweep away the place and not spare it for the fifty righteous who are in it?'
verses.comment: The role of the righteous in upholding the community prefigures intercessory themes from Abraham to Moses.

verses.text: 'Far be it from you to do such a thing, to kill the righteous with the wicked, so that the righteous fare as the wicked! Far be it from you! Shall not the Judge of all the earth do what is right?'
verses.comment: God as Judge of all is a key doctrine; here mercy and justice are balanced.

verses.text: The LORD said, 'If I find at Sodom fifty righteous within the city, then I will spare the whole place for their sake.'
verses.comment: Intercession can bring mercy to many; emphasizes the efficacy of prayer and the importance of the righteous.

verses.text: Abraham answered, 'Behold, I have undertaken to speak to the Lord, I who am but dust and ashes.'
verses.comment: Humility before God is necessary for proper prayer and intercession.

verses.text: 'Suppose five of the fifty righteous are lacking? Will you destroy the whole city for lack of five?' He said, 'I will not destroy it if I find forty-five there.'
verses.comment: God’s patience is shown as Abraham persists, signifying the depth of divine mercy.

verses.text: He again spoke to Him and said, 'Suppose there are forty found there?' He said, 'I will not do it for the sake of forty.'
verses.comment: The gradual reduction underscores the importance of every righteous person in the eyes of God.

verses.text: 'Let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak. Suppose thirty are found there?' He said, 'I will not do it if I find thirty there.'
verses.comment: God's willingness to hear persistent prayer models our own approach in meditative, repeated prayer.

verses.text: He said, 'Behold, I have undertaken to speak to the Lord. Suppose twenty are found there?' He said, 'I will not destroy it for the sake of twenty.'
verses.comment: Persistent, humble intercession shapes Abraham’s relationship with God and models faith's perseverance.

verses.text: He said, 'Oh let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak just once more. Suppose ten are found there?' He said, 'I will not destroy it for the sake of ten.'
verses.comment: Even a small remnant can bring mercy; this principle echoes through OT to NT in the salvation of faithful remnants.

verses.text: The LORD went His way, when He had finished speaking to Abraham, and Abraham returned to his place.
verses.comment: The dialogue closes with Abraham’s intercession and God’s justice remaining perfectly balanced; foreshadows the power of intercessory prayer and God's willingness to hear the prayers of the faithful.
